This award strives to support the science and practice of food, feed, and fiber production (including forestry, wildlife, fisheries, aquaculture and floriculture) and its relationships to natural resources, processing, marketing, distribution, utilization (including nutrition), and trade. In addition, this award On May 18-20, 2015, USDA-APHIS in cooperation with UN's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) supported a Good Emergency Management Practice (GEMP) training from in Cotonou – Benin to help strengthen Benin animal diseases national response team’s capacity to prevent and respond to diseases emergency threats. FAO experts facilitated the training which addressed topics that included GEMP concepts: Chain of command / Planning and Preparation / Detection & Prevention / Response & Recovery / Demonstration of contingency planning / Basic principles of a tabletop simulation exercise. At the conclusion of the activity the participants conducted a hot wash highlighting the need to take advantages of GEMP principles for the ongoing revision of the national contingency plans, the continued need to organize the training of trainers on the principles of GEMP to allow a wide dissemination of the tools, and the implementation of simulation exercises at national and local level to test the revised contingency plan.

description.narrative: The primary goal of U.S. assistance in Benin is to improve the health of Beninese families by reducing the malaria disease burden, improving the health of mothers and young children, and strengthening the overall health system to deliver quality, high impact interventions. Additionally, U.S. assistance helps professionalize Benin's military, which increases its ability to maintain domestic peace and security while contributing to regional stability.
